Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Insight into the reasons behind materials behaving the way they do.

We went over the basic properties of metals, ceramics, and polymers, the three main categories of materials. We discussed reactions, crystal structures, phase diagrams, and learned about different material properties.

Material sciences is about using the atomic properties of materials to explain the characteristics of such materials (metals, ceramics, polymers) in terms of their strength, ductility, corrosiveness, (ability to mix with other materials) and more. After learning about the properties of materials you can then analyze what type of materials would be optimal/best for building certain structures.

You learn a lot about materials, structures, etc. Some of the material overlaps with mechanical design (like stress strain curves and materials working) and strength and def (stress strain curve), but there is a whole lot more you learn. It's a lot of material and a class I hadn't really wanted to take, but I see the value in knowing this stuff, as it helps you design better.
This is a classic introductory course with a lot of different subjects.
VERY basic knowledge of material science. A lot of basic stuff

This class is a great introduction to materials science. We started at the quantum level looking at electron orbitals and ended up being able to explain nearly all properties of materials and why they act the way they do. I learned a lot from this class and found it to be very informative.

This class provided a good overview of how quantum mechanics, atomic structure, bonding, and micro structure cause materials to have various properties. I feel that I have learned a great deal about how these characteristics affect materials physical and chemical properties.
Interesting class but lectures were very slow and hard to learn from.
Learned basic material science concepts

We learned about metals, ceramics, and polymers, their properties and why these properties occur.  Though at first, this felt like a rehash of what we covered in genchem last year, the second half of the course especially was very interesting and seems quite applicable to my engineering interests.

You're probably taking this course because you have to but it's actually really interesting material. The professor clearly knows a lot about it and is an expert in materials science so his enthusiasm makes dry lectures more interesting.
everything from material classes to the atomic level.

Materials science gave a basic overview of the three classes of materialsmetals, ceramics, and polymerswith almost the whole semester focused on metals. We discussed bonds, crystal structures, dislocations, stress/strain diagrams, phase diagrams, and corrosion, among other topics. It's kinda like softcore chemistry. There's a focus on intuition about how something will behave.

I learned about how macro-scale properties of materials stem from their unique internal structures and chemical characteristics. It was insightful to learn and think about why certain materials behave the way they do, and how microstructures determine material properties and affect the design of mechanical systems.
I learned the basics of materials science and material properties.
I learned about how chemistry and materials science affects mechanical properties of materials.
I learned about different topics in materials sciences, including different types of materials as well as various material properties and what causes them.
Very dry (although informative) lectures.

The course has interesting material but it isn't taught very well. Lectures are based on slides and so there is a lot of talking but not much discussion student-wise or many examples. It could be improved by being more engaging - interacting more with the students and asking questions rather than speaking the whole time. It would also help to make sure everyone knows what certain things mean in lecture - oftentimes, certain concepts such as some from thermodynamics aren't explained but are central to the lecture.

The material of the course was good but it could be dry at times. You really have to be interested in the topic or simply dedicated to putting in the time to understand how all the different elements of the subject tie in together if you can't pay attention in class.

This class has psets done in partners, so as long as you have a good partner who helps you out, the workload is pretty low key and manageable. They grade very harshly on the homeworks, which ultimately are a large part of the final grade according to the syllabus, and the grading there doesn't match up with the midterm/final. I said the same thing and got 4 points less credit on the midterm than I did on the homework, which doesn't really make sense. I heard Jan will give points back, but TAs definitely won't and will even discourage you going to the teacher to get points back, as 'they don't like when students try to get points' according to the TAs. I think grading needs to be more uniform across everything we turn in.
It is a fun class, but the lectures could be more engaging.
Janne is awesome! The course is not very demanding, but gives good understanding of mat sci

The course was well structured and the problem sets did a good job of engaging us with the material. The only thing I found annoying about the course was the arbitrary grading by the TAs which put a lot of stress on the final exam.

The topics covered in class were mostly interesting and seemed relevant to the field of materials science. The lectures, however, nearly always strayed to a place where it was hard to follow what was going on, or see relevance to where we started. The psets consistently asked questions that had not even been mentioned in class in passing. We had only one midterm, and the questions on it were largely identical to a pset we had turned in that day which many people struggled with, so we got no real feedback before the exam. The grading seemed sporadic at best, with same answers getting different grades between students.

Overall this course was very good. I just wish there had been more on polymers, ceramics, and non mechanical properties, though I understand that its harder to draw conclusions with these topics; they're not as clear cut as metals.

I appreciated that lecture slides were posted online.  Lectures themselves were ok, but they were way to slow (especially for that time in the afternoon).  I liked the qualitative focus on the midterm and final- preparation was less memorizing random formulas and more trying to fully understand.

A big problem with the course was the ridiculous homework grading.  Comments were snarky and extremely anal. For example, there were times I would take an example of something directly from the textbook and would lose points (and get a really condescending comment) because the TF didn't recognize it. Sarcastic comments would be less annoying if there weren't grading mistakes!  When you lose points because the TF didn't like how you drew a line or whatever, it becomes a lot harder to figure out which mistakes you made that were actually important.

Also, office hours were just individuals asking questions about the hw, and the time and place was never really posted in a clear place on canvas.
More support to understand the material. Psets were very easy to finish but not much feedback on them.
Very fair, good textbook

Strengths:
If you're willing to self-learn, you can learn a lot

Weaknesses:
You learn nothing in the classroom. Also, the part where this class has no formal prerequisites is a complete lie. The BlueBook says, "Prerequisites: elementary calculus and background in basic mechanics (deformation, Hooke's law) and structure of atoms (orbitals, periodic table)" I'm sorry, but none of that prepares you for the prerequisite knowledge on Gibbs Free Energy, Thermodynamics, and Electrochemistry that this class expects you to have. 

It's full of seniors who are Mech E and Chem E majors who know all the stuff from before and hence take it as a gut class. The professor seems to acknowledge this too, and teaches the class accordingly (Or rather, he doesn't). The final exam was geared towards Chem E topics, which is why all of them knew everything. As a non-senior Mech E person, I felt pretty cheated by this class.

I enjoyed the lectures and generally found them helpful.  The problem sets did not seem to relate to the lectures, however.  I went through them by combining knowledge found in the book (usually different from class) with information found online.  I found both the lectures and the problem sets useful, though I would have liked to see them relate to each other more.
Partner problem sets were really weird, so maybe that should change and we should just do homework individually.
rather unorganized, no one ever knows what to expect on the exams

This course is strong in that the syllabus covers the right amount of material, and it doesn't feel too rushed or too slow. That said, we could spend a little less time on metals so we'd have more time to go over ceramics and polymers. The partner problem sets worked out pretty well for me, and I think the exams were pretty well-placed.

The prof. promises that the exams won't require you to learn equations (and does not provide an equation sheet) so both tests ended up being a bunch of writing questions on a particular set of conceptual questions that weren't even explained that well in class. I wished the tests had used an equation sheet and included a few more problems like the homework, or the existing exams would have been okay if Jan's explanations had been clearer in class.

I also had a very hard time understanding phase diagrams and Gibbs Free Energy from the lectures. Please try to make these lectures clearer, and go over how to draw Gibbs Energy curves before assigning them for homework.

strengths: not too fast paced, jan cares about the students, relatively interesting material that is more theoretical in nature than quantitative. 


weaknesses: class can be a bit slow moving at times, wide variety of backgrounds, the fact that is it more qualitative means that sometimes it is unclear what the instructor is looking for on exams, homework

The course could be improved by making the lectures more structured. If the lectures more closely followed the syllabus and were better defined the topics they covered, the class would be stronger. Furthermore, receiving better feedback on our assignments and having clearer lecture notes would be very helpful. I really enjoyed how competent and passionate Professor Schroers was in our class.
The material was interesting but some of the more advanced topics would be easier to understand if I had a background in thermo.
The professor was nice but the class was far too disorganized.

Overall a useful course for me, but I thought the material could have used more depth.  While some of this is simply because this is an introductory course in materials science, perhaps skipping some of the basic chemistry components and taking the time to delve deeper into bonding and structure analysis and phase relations, etc. would be more valuable.

The biggest strength of this course was that we got a very nice overview of materials science. I especially liked how the course was structured, with each topic building on the previous one, and it was nice seeing how the different topics were related to practical applications in engineering and design. I think the main way that the course could be improved is that the lectures could have been more focused. In a given lecture, we talked about a lot of different stuff, so it was sometimes hard to figure out what concepts were important. I also wish discussion sections were used to go over material from lecture, rater than just an opportunity to ask questions like you would in office hours. Although I appreciated being able to ask questions on what I was confused about, I think it would have been more helpful if the sections were more structured.

the strength of this course was the relatively small class size, it made it possible for us to occasionally work in groups to answer questions and go over information, however we were paired up for homework and my partner left me out to dry every week and maybe responded once to my texts or emails.
I generally would not recommend this course. It can be difficult to follow and to understand what is being said sometimes, which makes the class frustrating even though the material is interesting.

Pretty helpful in terms of knowing how to design things well. Manageable workload, as you do homeworks with a partner. Definitely do all the homeworks, though, and understand them, as that's a good prediction of what is on exams.
Take it if you need an easy Mech E elective.
It's ok. Great professor that will grow on you.
This is a great class if you are interested in studying materials science. I highly recommend to anyone, including physics majors like myself.
Don't take this class unless you have to. Even though the field is incredibly interesting, lectures were boring and unhelpful, and exams were unpredictable and not weighted to how we spent our time.
I would definitely recommend this course. You will learn a lot about the basics of material properties and why different materials exhibit different properties.
This course is very interesting and not too difficult. Workload is light.
Honestly on the better side of engineering courses I've taken so far!
You're probably taking this class because you have to. If it's an elective, please dodge this bullet and never take it.

This class, once you get the hang of what the TAs are looking for in the problem sets, isn't too difficult, especially if you have a good partner who is dedicated to working together on the homework.  It's pretty interesting and I would recommend it to all B.S. Mech Es as an elective.
Yes, pretty interesting stuff and necessary for any engineer to understand.
Yes, interesting a chill mech e elective. Jan is engaging. workload is light.

I was happy I picked Materials Science for my MechE B.A. because it's pretty fundamental stuff to mechanical engineering. I also appreciated that it wasn't excessively difficult in terms of workload, unlike a lot of other MechE classes. That said, I found the lectures to be frequently unengaging and felt like the course material could have been taught a lot better. All in all, though, not a bad class, and Jan is a kind prof.

You're probably taking this because you're MechE anyways, but don't worry too much about this one. Workload isn't too high and the midterm is fair. Be warned though, the material from the end sneaks up on you and the final is pretty hard.
Yes

Unfortunately not well taught. The class material is actually quite exciting and useful, however, the course is rather disorganized overall. Although the material isn't conceptually very difficult, there is a lot to learn and a lot of material is covered. A revamp of the course structure would make it into a very good class.
Dont take this course. Instructor did not post solutions to hmwk or exams. No clesr feedback on grades in the course. Exams and hmwk did not follow lecture. Pass.
Yes, it is a very interesting course
Take it if you are interested in materials science, as it's a useful intro for aerospace and materials related fields, but not superbly useful otherwise.
I would recommend this course to someone who wants to learn more about materials science or have a basic understanding of the topic.
